p: Householdsâ€™ livelihoods in most rural communities in South Africa, like elsewhere in Africa, are highly dependent on forest resources (Charnley 2005; Clarke & Isaacs 2005; Davies, Oswald & Mitchell 2008; Malone & Rovere 2012; Hachileka 2009; Mertz et al. 2009), with farming, animal husbandry, and harvesting and trade in forest resources being the dominant livelihood activities (Chamberlain et al. 2005; Kyei 2011; Vhembe 2013). Forest resources are in essence highly crucial for rural development in South Africa. However, observed and predicted impact of climate change is projected to have an extensive range of consequences, many of which represent major threats, for example droughts, flash floods and decline in crop productivity, among others (Bryan et al. 2009; Capstick 2012; Chinara et al. 2013; Kalinda 2011; Mengistus 2011; Mertz et al. 2009; Sarah et al. 2012). This impact also poses significant threat to forests, livelihoods and rural development which might result into increased intensity of poverty.
